Focus on Processing, Not Forgetting:

Accepting the past:
 While you can't change the past, you can choose how you react to it. Accepting that the event happened and that you cannot control it can be a powerful first step.

Understanding the impact:
 Explore the emotional and psychological impact the trauma has had on you. Talking to a therapist or counselor can be invaluable in this process.

Developing coping mechanisms:
 Learn healthy ways to manage difficult emotions and flashbacks triggered by memories. This could include relaxation techniques like deep breathing, meditation, or mindfulness exercises.

Reduce Intrusive Thoughts:

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): 
This therapy helps identify and challenge negative thought patterns that fuel intrusive thoughts. A therapist can guide you through CBT techniques.

Distraction techniques:
 When intrusive thoughts arise, try engaging in activities that require your full attention, like reading, listening to music, or spending time with loved ones.

Grounding techniques:
 These exercises help bring your focus back to the present moment and reduce the intensity of intrusive thoughts. Examples include focusing on your senses, naming objects around you, or repeating calming mantras.

Remember:

Healing takes time and patience: Don't expect to "get over" trauma quickly. Be kind to yourself and celebrate your progress, no matter how small.

Focus on the present and future: While acknowledging the past, remember that you have the power to shape your present and future. Focus on building a fulfilling life filled with positive experiences.
